vocabulary.english: enclitic particle that means already or now

contents.markdown: If you do not have Tagalog numbers memorized, or need a refresher, please go to **Appendix D** and make a first pass at memorizing pure Tagalog numbers, ordinal numbers and fractions before attempting this lesson. You are shown how to form them in Appendix D, and the numbers are listed out there too. This lesson is meant to show you how to put them to use.
<u>Cardinal numbers (one, two, three, etc.)</u>
Cardinal numbers are very flexible. Here are a few examples. You can use them with age:
Q : Ilang + **taon**_ _+ na + subject? (Tag.) = How old is subject? (Eng.)
**Note: Subject takes _ang_ form.**

item.tagalog: Ilang taon na po ang lalaki?

contents.markdown: Notice that _ilan_ takes a linker, changing it to _ilang_, before nouns. There is a _na_ in the sentence too, but it is not the linker. It is an enclitic particle that adds the meaning “already” or “now”. When you ask someone their age, remember to use it because it sounds unnatural not to.
\*\*Note: _Na_ is an enclitic particle. Enclitic particles appear in a fixed order. You have learned three so far, and they appear in this order: _na, po, ba_.\*\*
Remember that short personal pronouns like _ka_ come before enclitic particles like _na_. Here is how to answer “how old” questions:
A: Number + _taon_+ na + subject. (Tag.) = Subject is number years old now. (Eng.)
**Note: Subject takes _ang_ form.**
Shorter Ans: Dalawampu’t isa. = Twenty-one.

item.tagalog: Apatnapu't tatlong taon na po ang lalaki.
item.english: The man is forty-three years old. (resp.)

contents.markdown: Notice that the numbers take linkers before the noun _taon_. That is because they are merely adjectives modifying the noun, as seen previously.
**Note: Numbers are adjectives, and should be treated as such, but they do not require the plural marker _mga_.**
_Mga_ is normally dropped with numbers, and so that is what we will do in this book.
You can count with cardinal numbers:
Cardinal numbers are also handy for buying stuff:
<u>Ordinal numbers (first, second, third, etc.)</u>
Tagalog ordinal numbers are not used very often, but you will hear them from time to time:
<u>Fractions</u>
As noted in **Appendix D**, the only Tagalog fraction that is often used in colloquial speech is _kalahati_, which means “half”:

item.tagalog: Kalahating tsokolate at kalahating tubig ang inumin.
item.english: The drink is half chocolate and half water.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Ilang taon na ang pagod na babaeng yun?
exampleSentences.english: How old is that tired woman?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Walumpu't siyam na taon na siya at walang pera.
exampleSentences.english: She is eighty-nine years old and has no money.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Magkano ang dalawa mong tsokolateng bahay?
exampleSentences.english: How much are your two chocolate houses?
Do you have half a chicken?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Magkano ang mga mainit ninyong inumin?
exampleSentences.english: How much are your hot drinks?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Apatnapu't pitong piso po ang bawat inumin namin.
exampleSentences.english: Each of our drinks is forty-seven pesos. (resp.)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Ito ang ikalawa kong murang sasakyan.
exampleSentences.english: This is my second, cheap car.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Hindi kalahating adobo at kalahating tubig ang pagkain natin!
exampleSentences.english: Our (incl.) food is not half adobo and half water!
